creator: blau21212121

content:
Chyba neznamená špatné heslo, ale nevyhovující způsob přihlášení. Řešením je povolit IMAP a použít heslo pro poštovní klienty, nikoli běžné heslo k účtu.

1) Přihlas se do webmailu na účtu u Seznam.cz 2) Nastavení účtu → Zabezpečení 3) Zkontroluj / zapni Přístup přes poštovní klienty (IMAP/POP3) 4) Vygeneruj heslo pro poštovní klienty 5) V poštovním programu nahraď původní heslo tímto novým

Správné nastavení IMAP: 

  – Server: imap.seznam.cz   – Port: 993   – Zabezpečení: SSL/TLS   – Ověření: normální heslo   – Uživatelské jméno: celá e-mailová adresa

Na co si dát pozor: 

  – běžné přihlašovací heslo často už nestačí,   – změna hesla na webu problém nevyřeší

Po několika neúspěšných pokusech může Seznam přístup krátce blokovat (počkat desítky minut).
creator: poljos-moz

content: Děkuji moc funguje to.
creator: blau21212121

content:
If he account is IMAP, the only solution is to create the account, not copy it. If it is a POP account, you could first copy the existing mail\<POP account folder>, set up the POP account on the other computer, and then paste the copied contents into the account folder, overlaying the default contents. Do the paste when thunderbird is NOT running and before you start retrieving new messages.

TIP: when copying profiles from one computer to another, and IF the accounts are IMAP, just exit thunderbird, in imapmail\<IMAP account folder>, just delete the inbox and other folders, and the profile will be much smaller than 8 gig. Thunderbird will repopulate the message folders.

content: This forum is not supported by developers, but by peer users like you. We do not make these decisions. In general, Thunderbird does not support or debug addons; that is the developer role. Also, by using the latest release, you are more likely to encounter addon issues, as developers must be continually involved with latest updates. it is routine for users to post that an addon isn't working properly with the latest release. If reliable results from addons is a priority, my personal recommendation is to stick with the ESR release. My opinion - and it's nothing more than that - is that the developer has direct contact with the appropriate persons and could probably work through this issue better. If you believe there is a bug in Thunderbird, you can post it at bugzilla.mozilla.org.
creator: davidsk

content:
Thanks David, That makes it clearer then that my query doesn't get picked up by Mozilla.

I didn't know there was a choice of versions one being ESR as you say.

I still don't understand the "AMO" term though.

I may have answered my own question by digging deeper. The XPI file has a manifest.json file which shows "strict_max_version": "145.*" even though the developer documentation shows compatibility up to 147. I think that puts it in the developer's court.

I even tried to edit the json file to change the number to 147, filed it and re-zipped it up. That didn't work when I tried to install from a local file, as it said it was corrupted. I've given up at this point and restored to the older version 144 of thunderbird.
creator: itdcmy

content:
I still don't understand the "AMO" term though.

AMO stands for addons.mozilla.org. Technically it isn't entirely correct to refer to AMO for Thunderbird add-ons, as Thunderbird uses it's own add-on store at https://addons.thunderbird.net.

The latest version of the 'Allow HTML Temp' add-on is 10.1.1, and it's marked as compatible up to TB v147. https://addons.thunderbird.net/thunderbird/addon/allow-html-temp/

That version works just fine here with TB 146.0.1. Why it doesn't work for you I don't know. Perhaps you disabled automatic add-on updates in Thunderbird?

With the latest version of the add-on you shouldn't need to mess with the max_version option in the manifest.json file. I'd suggest to remove the messed up version of the add-on in your installation of Thunderbird, restart Thunderbird, and then install the latest version via the Thunderbird Add-on Manager. Also see https://support.mozilla.org/kb/installing-addon-thunderbird
creator: christ1

content: Thunderbird switched from one release to two earlier this year: a monthly version that would receive latest features, and the ESR version that receives an annual release and support patches through the year. the ESR release is at 140, while monthly is at 146. If interested in the ESR, this URL may help, although switching to a prior release sometimes creates its own problems: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-release if addons remain vital to you, and you wish to stay with the monthly release, you may want to change the automatic update to just notify - that is done at settings>general.
creator: davidsk

content: Two tips: - click settings>privacy&security to verify that you allow remote content - click view>message body as and verify that you have it set to original HTML (if menu bar not visible, press alt key first)
creator: davidsk

content:
General instructions are at https://kb.mozillazine.org/Moving_your_profile_folder_-_Thunderbird I encourage that the receiving thunderbird be at least at same release as from the sending computer. I've done this several times and it works The profile manager works well. A modification of the profile manager approach is this: - exit thunderbird - make a copy of the profile - install thunderbird on linux, start and then exit - copy the windows profile and paste over the top of the active linux profile and you're done. Do this when thunderbird not running.

If unsure how to find profile location, these steps work on windows and linux: - click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder' - exit thunderbird and you will be in the profile
creator: davidsk
